copy.en-US: Some outro text

Authors often want full freedom when composing a piece of editorial content out of sub elements such as blocks of text, images, videos, headlines. While an old CMS could give you basic capabilities out of the box, thanks to a modular approach, Contentful enables lets you achieve greater modularity a flexibility. By using reference fields, you are capable of linking entries to other entries, and manage them in any way you want. With this approach, a _module_ content type holds content only, and has no information about how it is displayed. All these concerns are delegated to the entry that is embedding the module.

## About

This app is an imaginary online learning platform that we call The Example App. The goal in creating this app is to provide you with an example Contentful space connected to an example application which help teach you how content is managed using Contentful, and delivered to authenticated apps using powereful APIs. It should make clear the connection between content that lives in a space in Contentful and the applications leveraging Contentful's SDKs to pull that content.

In the [Contentful web app](https://app.contentful.com), you can make copy of this space so you can make content changes and see them propagate in the app—make sure to update the _Space ID_ and the _Delivery API Key_ in the settings page of this app to connect your copy of the space to this app.

You can also browse the code for this app to learn best practices for development when using Contentful's SDKs. Contentful offers officially supported SDK's in JavaScript, Ruby, Java, Python, .Net, PHP, and Swift, so we've made sure to provide a separate implementation of this app in all of those languages so you can get the most out of this reference, no matter what language you write code in.

## Imprint

title.en-US: code snippets for search on reference

python.en-US:
from contentful import Client

client = Client('<space_id>', '<content_delivery_api_key>')

related_entry = client.entries({
    'content_type': '<content_type_id>',
    'fields.bestFriend.sys.contentType.sys.id': 'cat',
    'fields.bestFriend.fields.name[match]': 'Happy Cat'
})

ruby.en-US:
require 'contentful'

client = Contentful::Client.new(
  space: '<space_id>',
  access_token: '<content_delivery_api_key>',
  dynamic_entries: :auto  # Enables Content Type caching.
)

related_entry = client.entries(
  content_type: '<content_type_id>',
  'fields.bestFriend.sys.contentType.sys.id' => 'cat',
  'fields.bestFriend.fields.name[match]' => 'Happy Cat'
)

shortDescription.en-US: Learn the nitty gritty details of content modeling.

description.en-US: Content modelling is the practice of structuring your content by grouping information into logical elements. We call these logical elements _content types_, and we populate the relevant information in the _fields_ for these content types. Relationships can also be made between content types enabling you to model complex information. This course will teach you all the nitty, gritty details of content modeling, giving you tips and tricks to help you build a flexible and powerful content model.

shortDescription.en-US: How does this application you are currently browsing through actually work?

description.en-US:
The example application was made to be used as a reference while you make your first steps with Contentful. By looking at the code, you should get a sense of how to use our SDKs. While using the code, you may notice some third party dependencies that were used in writing the app, but we will not teach you these frameworks. Instead, we’ll focus on solidifying your understanding of Contentful in code so you can build your applications using one of our SDKs.

The example application has a separate implementation for each programming language that Contentful offers an official SDK for. You're advised to select the appropriate programming language to get the most out of the code samples you'll see.

title.en-US: Fetching an entry with the SDK
How we modelled content for this app
Serving content in the right language
Fetch draft content with the SDK
The connection between this app and Contentful's Web app

shortDescription.en-US: This is an example to reference while building your own apps with Contentful. This course explains fetching content and creating a custom UI.

description.en-US:
This is an example built to serve as a reference for building your own applications using Contentful. It is an online learning platform in which the courses teach how Contentful was used to build this app (so meta)! The content is pulled from Contentful’s APIs via our different SDKs. The user-interface is custom built for this application and _not_ a template provided by Contentful. As you will learn in this course, not providing a template is one of the defining features of a headless CMS.

In just about 5 minutes, this course will explain the basics of how Contentful can be used to manage content in your production applications. It will demonstrate important concepts by showing how this example application was built and how the content it renders was modelled.

Questions that will be answered in this course:

- **Contentful's architecture:** What are the basic aspects of Contentful?
- **Content model:** How was the data that this app is rendering modelled?
- **Integrating with Contentful:** How was __*this*__ app built and how does it connect to Contentfuls APIs?


If you prefer to get your hands dirty right away, check out this app on [Github](https://images.contentful.com/82t39nctsu20/1JOkYZnY8YG0w88ImweME2/c8aef71dfe1ea633e16e17d99379416c/Github-repo_2x__1_.png).

copy.en-US:
The bulk of a content type definition is made up by a list of fields. We can distinguish two fundamental types of fields: simple, and arrays. A _simple_ field is one that contains a single piece of information, which can be of many types:

- `Symbol`: a short text field for titles and names, with maximum length set at 256 characters.
- `Text`: a long text field for paragraphs of text. Filterable via full-text search. Maximum length is 50,000 characters.
- `Integer`: a whole number, which can range from -2^53^ to 2^53^.
- `Number`: any decimal number, ranging from -2^53^ to 2^53^.
- `Date`: a date string, formatted using the ISO 8601 standard.
- `Location`: a JSON object, containing coordinates using `lat` and `lon` properties.
- `Boolean`: a simple `true`-`false` value.
- `Object`: a raw JSON string.
- `Link`: a link to an entry or an asset.


As you can see, most of the common data types are present. In case of something more complex, you could use the `Object` type, which you can then structure however you want on a per-entry basis.

Array fields in Contentful represent a list of values, which can contain either symbols, links to assets, or links to entries. Array fields let you easily model complex 1:N relations, such as a product with many images, but if you get creative you can have paragraphs in an article, highlighted articles in an homepage, and so on. Together with links, arrays form the fundamental building block for content composition with Contentful, and the possibilities are endless.

On the right you see the *Contentful Web app*. It is a single page application Contentful provides to help with the most common tasks when managing content:

- provide an interface for editors to write content
- provide an interface for developers to configure aspects of a space (e.g. data modelling, roles and permissions, webhook notifications)

Technically speaking the *Contentful Web app* is a client of our Content Management API. That means all functionality provided by the *Contentful Web app* is also available directly through our management API. This is a powerful aspect of an API-first design as it facilitates interoperability with third party systems.

## Understanding context vs content

An important thing we should understand is the difference between a _context_ content type and a _content_ content type. The difference is subtle but important. While they are both used to store data, their purpose is different. In fact, one (_context_) will be used to describe a webpage, a view in an app, or any other concept that is context-dependent. These content types will often contain certain metadata which is necessary for the app to work: for instance, the content type called _Course_ contains the field `slug`. Although this field is not necessarily shown in the webpage you see about the course, it is necessary for the app in order for the routing mechanism to work. This field is very much context-aware: it is useful only when working in a website context, whereas it becomes almost meaningless in an app.

The opposite of this kind of content types are those whose main purpose is to store content. In this app, these content types are called _modules_. Although they can still store metadata (in fact, some of those also contain a `slug` field), it's usually for convenience rather than for actual need. They are almost never used standalone, as they usually behave more as building blocks that are implemented by context content types.

Of course, not everything's black or white. Although separating context and content is usually a good design pattern which helps scaling, not all situations are complex enough that this makes sense. To sum up, when you think about how to design a content model, ask yourself: _does it make sense to break this into reusable bits?_ Sometimes you can sacrifice some flexibility in the name of ease of use: if the requirements are not too complex, it's a perfectly valid choice.

In this section, we got some insights into how sample application was built using our SDKs. We encourage you to download the source code and interact with it to deepen your learning. If you have further questions please do not hesitate submit an issue or pull request, contact us in our Contentful Community or our Community Slack.

👋

Errors can happen, but there are ways to prevent them from sneaking into production. Think about the case of a blog post without a title, or with a duplicated slug: these are the mistakes that can break an app. This is why it's important to master field validation.

Even without directly working with the CMA API, you can define complex rules using the Contentful Web App. After creating the field, go to its validation settings and you'll find all avaiable options for the current field type:

One important aspect of content delivery is authentication. Without the necessary credentials, your content is innaccesible, even for read-only operations via the CDA. These credentials are the identifier for your space in Contentful, and your delivery API key, also referred to as an access token.

You will need an access token to build applications on top of Contentful, so let's find out where they're hidden. First, login to Contentful at app.contentful.com and navigate to the space your going to build an application around. In the navigation bar at the top of the screen, you'll see a section called "APIs", where you can grab keys for Contentful's various APIs.

title.en-US: Example Application - Locale - Fetch - Code - Success

copy.en-US: You can see in the top right of the he example application, there is a switch to change the language from German to English to see how localization support in action.

The last thing we want to mention here is the ability to change the language of the content on the fly. If you have your content model setup with different locales, retrieving resources in a different language is as easy as doing the following:

title.en-US: Example Application - Preview - Credentials full Code - Success

copy.en-US: Using a client with the above configuration, the SDK will fetch content from the preview API and return content which is not yet published. To see this in action, toggle between the CDA and CPA using the switch on the screen. Additionally, go back to the WebApp and change one of the pieces of content you're viewing, but don't publish! Now, when toggling between CDA and CPA, you should see your drafted changes!

title.en-US: Example Application - Walk-through of JavaScript App - Services

copy.en-US:
A service is a module that makes communicating with a part of your app easy. It is recommended to wrap Contentful into one service since this makes unit testing easier and serves separation of concerns.

This service offers simple functionalities, mostly based on the Content Types defined:
⚪ Get the landing page content type
⚪ Get all courses of the Contentful space
⚪ And more

There could be more services, potentially one for each backend integrated, or different services for massaging the data. Since we try to keep it simple, this is the only service we are going into more details here.

title.en-US: Example Application - Preview - Credentials full Code

dotNet.en-US:
var httpClient = new HttpClient();
var client = new ContentfulClient(httpClient, "d88b119e4459b1343ed2753004fb229d77db76b81adec3b70b933285660e8db3", "82t39nctsu20", usePreviewApi: true);

ruby.en-US:
require ‘contentful’

client = Contentful::Client.new(
  space: '82t39nctsu20',
  access_token: 'd88b119e4459b1343ed2753004fb229d77db76b81adec3b70b933285660e8db3',
  dynamic_entries: :auto,
  api_url: 'preview.contentful.com',
  raise_errors: true
)

title.en-US: Example Application - Walk-through of JavaScript App - Views

copy.en-US:
A view uses an external dependency, called PUG, and converts the data model coming from Contentful, into an HTML string, which then can get returned by the route, so the user can see it on if they browse to the website.

So going from services, through routes to views summarizes the way our sample app displays published content from Contentful.

In addition to serving published content, Contentful can also serve draft content: we call this preview, and a resource is a preview resource as long as it is not published. To access those resources, you need to interface with the preview API.

The preview API accepts the same parameters and returns the same payload structure as the delivery API. This makes is very easy to switch any client application between these two APIs 

The SDKs are also making it easier for you to use preview. Remember the code for initializing the SDK from above? You can just adapt it to be using preview, by adding two parameters to the configuration:

title.en-US: Example Application - Walk-through of JavaScript App - Routes

copy.en-US:
What is a route? It is not just the way to get to the next grocery shop, but also the URL the web server should handle.

For instance, there is an index.js route, which defines routes like the root, or other top-level entry points into the app. Every route communicates with a service to request the models to be rendered. The rendering (the converting of data models into an HTML page) will be taken care of by several views.

title.en-US: Example Application - SDK Getting Data - Introduction Code - Success

copy.en-US: You can see that there is an entry ID specified. This ID will be used to fetch the entry and return it. In the code above, we assign the fetched entry to a variable called `entry` in the callback.

title.en-US: Example Application - SDK Getting Data - Introduction Code
Example Application - SDK Initialization - Code - Success

copy.en-US: This code first includes the library and then configures a client by providing the space ID and Content Delivery API key to read from this space.
After installing, you need to include the SDK into your current project and configure it. As a simple example, please consider the following code:

title.en-US: Example Application - SDK Getting Data - Introduction

copy.en-US: Now that you have setup a Contentful client, you can use it to retrieve data from Contentful.

dotNet.en-US:
var httpClient = new HttpClient();
var client = new ContentfulClient(httpClient, "2a8dad8e545fc9f5c6aa9250f8a819f87049545260b4041688e708744d1b01c6", "82t39nctsu20");

ruby.en-US:
require ‘contentful’

client = Contentful::Client.new(
  space: '82t39nctsu20',
  access_token: '2a8dad8e545fc9f5c6aa9250f8a819f87049545260b4041688e708744d1b01c6',
  dynamic_entries: :auto,
  raise_errors: true
)

copy.en-US:
If you have ever communicated with a RESTful HTTP server without using an SDK, you know that sometimes keeping track of endpoints can be difficult. Forgot the HTTP-Header? How was the order of URL path elements again? Did the space parameter come first or second?

To make communication with Contentful as easy as possible, we created our open source SDKs. You install them, initialize them, and immediately have the power of the Contentful API at your fingertips, without needing to remember the intricate details.

Assuming a solid understanding of your language and frameworks, you start using the Contentful SDK by importing it like so:

title.en-US: Example Application - SDK Installation - Code - Success

copy.en-US: This command will install the Contentful SDK.

The example application has a separate implementation for each programming language that Contentful offers an official SDK for. You're advised to select the appropriate programming language to get the most out of the code samples you'll see.

Developing with Contentful starts with adding the SDK as a dependency into your project.

Since we are going to write code in your favorite language, we assume you have some understanding of it first. If you think your understanding can be a bit better, feel free to freshen up a bit on it, and return here, whenever you feel comfortable.

Assuming a solid understanding of your language and frameworks, you start using the Contentful SDK by importing it like so:

title.en-US: Example Application Introduction - Scope of the app

copy.en-US: The example application was made to be used as a reference while you make your first steps with Contentful. By looking at the code, you should get a sense of how to use our SDKs. While using the code, you may notice some third party dependencies that were used in writing the app, but we will not teach you these frameworks. Instead, we’ll focus on solidifying your understanding of Contentful in code so you can build your applications using one of our SDKs.

headline.en-US: A referenceable example for developers using Contentful

copy.en-US:
This is The Example App, an application built to serve you as a reference while building your own applications using Contentful. This app is an online learning platform which teaches you how Contentful was used to build this app (so meta)!

If you prefer to start by getting your hands dirty with code, check out this app on [Github](https://images.contentful.com/82t39nctsu20/1JOkYZnY8YG0w88ImweME2/c8aef71dfe1ea633e16e17d99379416c/Github-repo_2x__1_.png).

## API-first

Understanding Contentful's basic architecture is key. 

Contentful's infrastructure is running on Amazon Web Services (AWS) and follows an API-first approach. It means that all functionality is provided through an API.

> __» Contentful is 100% cloud-based and all functionality is provided through APIs «__

A few examples are:
- you can modify data schemas or configure a webhook through the Content Management API.
- you can deliver content everywhere through the Content Delivery API.
- you can access unpublished (draft) content through the Content Preview API.
- you can resize, crop or re-compress images through the Images API.

## Headless
Contentful is a headless CMS. This means that there is no templating or presentation layer tied to the content. Instead it gives developers complete freedom when it comes to building applications presenting content from Contentful.

The benefit: you can fully decouple your applications from Contentful's services. The only dependencies coming with Contentful are:
- support for HTTP
- support for JSON (parsing)

You are free to choose whatever technology and presentation format that is most suited to _your_ needs.

Important terms when working with data in Contentful are

- content modelling
- content types
- fields

__Content modelling__ is the practice of structuring your content by grouping information into logical elements, called __content types__. 

You then populate the content types with __fields__. Each field represents one piece of data of a specific type.

Content types can also reference each other enabling you to model complex information relationships. 

## The content model of this lesson

The characters you are seeing while reading this lesson are data stored in Contentful. Lets have a look how that was modelled:
> __» Contentful adds no dependencies to your applications as long as it supports HTTP and can parse JSON «__

- Lesson (used to group and arrange content)
- Lesson > Copy (one chunk of markdown content)
- Lesson > Image (an image)
- Lesson > Code Snippet (holds code snippets for different languages, not used in this lesson)

To model a _lesson_, we chose a modular approach where the content type _Lesson_ uses a reference field holding references to other content types.

This approach comes with many benefits. Editors can customize the content and layout of a lesson and are not tied down to a specific order of fields.  Developers can develop and maintain the presentation of each content type individually.

> __Editors get as much control as possible, Developers keep as much control as required.__

In the diagram below the content types ancestors to a _lesson_ are shown. If you navigate back to the home section you can see the _highlighted course_ that the _layout_ defines. This _course_ holds a number of _lessons_. 

Identifying these connections help to understand the architecture of this application.

In the most basic case, integration with Contentful consists of a client application consuming content, while using the _Contentful Web app_ to manage content. There are much more complex examples possible, but this is a good starting point.

## Connecting the dots
_This example app_ (yes, **THIS** app) acts as the content consumer. It is a custom application and a reference implementation around a Contentful SDK. In total we are supporting eight different languages. If this example is not using your preferred language, feel free to switch: [The Example App Enchilada](https://github.com/pugjs/pug)

In the diagram below this app is on the left consuming content through our Delivery, Preview and Images APIs.

In the Hello World course you learned the basic concepts of Contentful. To summarize this is what we were covering:

- Contentful is an API-first system to facilitate interoperability with other systems.
- Contentful's content infrastructure is a service running 100% on Amazon Web Services.
- Contentful is headless and provides JSON and binaries as output. Your applications consuming content provide their own presentation.
- Contentful uses a data schema where content types and content are flexible, decoupled from presentation and can be controlled programmatically.
- Contentful provides a Web app to work with content and to configure many aspects of the system.


> __» This application is a reference implementation following best practices using a Contentful SDK . It is available in [8 different SDKs](http://example.com) «__
